content:
My preferred method is to open the new PC copy, use the help menu > troubleshooting to get to the troubleshooting information and then click the show profile folder button. That shows where Thunderbird thinks all your profile should be and convincing it that it is actually somewhere else appears to be getting harder

Now close the new Thunderbird.

Copy the contents of your old machine profile folder into the one that just opened including sub folders, it will replace files if you are copying everything correctly so expect warning of that nature. If you do not get then your copy is not in the right place.

Once you have done the copying start Thunderbird and it should "just work"
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Claranet heeft geen actuele serverinstellingen op de website staan, althans, ik kan ze niet vinden (alleen wat achterhaalde instructies over instellen van POP-e-mail, terwijl IMAP tegenwoordig de standaard is). Ik zou adviseren contact op te nemen met Claranet over wat uw serverinstellingen zouden moeten zijn. Aan de hand van dit artikel kunt u deze instellingen dan corrigeren voor uw account in Thunderbird.

U zou ook kunnen overwegen de account gewoon opnieuw toe te voegen. Voeg de account gewoon opnieuw toe aan Thunderbird (hoe dat gaat leest u hier). Schakel de synchronisatie van uw huidige account uit (waar u geen berichten meer op ontvangt) om onnodige aanmeldpogingen daarmee te voorkomen. Op die manier behoudt u de berichten die u al binnen hebt gehaald. Als u momenteel IMAP gebruikt, dan is dit laatste niet nodig en kunt u na nogmaals toevoegen van uw account uw huidige account gewoon verwijderen; er wordt dan automatisch gesynchroniseerd met de server.

content:
These steps work:


BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
I know it is strange, but thunderbird is application software that runs on your device. No one else has any access to it. So if you have a problem you are the one that has to fix it.

content: When Thunderbird attempts to connect and is refused it assumes the password has changed and asks you for it. SO what mail provider and what authentication method are you using. It sounds like it might be some sort of two factor authentication when you should be using something else like oauth.

content:
Su Win10 il problema non si presenta. Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
@z12: I recently had a similar problem with one of my folders in Local Folders. The folder name was "TotalEnergies", two weeks ago I saw that TB had renamed it to TotalEnergies77863ee3 and the folder was empty already the mbox file still had a size of 9.6 MB. Renaming the file in TotalEnergies didn't bring back the messages. Some user in the German TB forum having a similar problem when importing mbox files from Postbox. Eventually he could "repair" the mbox file by editing it in BBEdit and saving it as .xml file. I succeeded to repair my mbox file with the same method. Note that both files were repaired on Macs. The problem seems to be that mbox files ending with bare CR linings don't work in Thunderbird : https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1942540 "Support mbox files with bare CR line endings (produced on Mac pre Thunderbird 1.0)"

You could install BBEdit, open your recalcitrant mbox file in BBEdit and try to save it using one or another of the three line breaks as shown in my last screen shot
creator: Mapenzi

content: I resolved the issue by turning off my VPN thru McAfee. Is there a problem with Thunderbird running with McAfee VPN on?

content: Email clients all have trouble with VPNs because they tend to interrupt the client-to-server validation that SMTP servers demand. I think there is a setting in McAfee to disable email scanning, as I've seen that mentioned on other posts.

content:
Thunderbird is a computer program that runs on your device. It is not a web site and nothing is processed anywhere but on your local machine.

Now given that you are the only one that can see what is going on because everything happens on your local machine. Perhaps you might drop a bread crumb or two to those you are asking for help.

Perhaps share the error message you are seeing and describe what you are trying to do. Do you have an antivirus product installed? DO you have the same issues with it disabled? Do you use a VPN? Does the outcome change if you turn it off?
creator: MattAuSupport
